284$Condition: Depression$7/24/2011 10:09:18 PM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I know that a lot of people say they have had problems coming off this medication but that is not always the case.  If you carefully follow your doctor's instructions there are a number of things you can do to make the transition quite manageable (including decreasing the dose very slowly and adding a drug like Prozac).  Never stop taking Effexor without your doctor's instructions but don't be frightened away from a medication that may help your life feel worth living again.  I have been taking 300mg/day Effexor for over a year now and it is the very best thing that has helped me manage my depression.  I have always followed my Doctor's instructions and have not had any problems with the medication.  I do have to be very careful not to miss a dose though or I experience a lot of dizziness and anxiety.  I have been treated for severe depressive disorder for about 6 years and have taken a number of different different medications as part of my treatment (including Prozac
column2: Wellbutrin
column3: and Lamictal).  I was only getting minimal benefit from depression medications when my PCP was prescribing them but since I started seeing a psychiatrist and she put me on Effexor I have been managing so so so much better (even when my Mom died of cancer last year).  I highly recommend getting a psychiatrist and talking with them about all the pros and cons if you are considering taking Effexor.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$4$4$"Started taking this med about 6 years ago now for depression and anxiety after celexa went generic and was no longer effective for me. I take 150mg/day. Is pretty effective although some days I feel like a need a larger dose. I don't really notice any side effects when I take it correctly but like other writers have mentioned DO NOT miss a dose or withdrawl kicks in immediately. I ran out once and missed 2 days and thought I had the flu or mono for a week. I can always tell immediatly if I've forgotten to take my medicine within a about 4 hours.

column1: Remember not every medication works for every person. Also when 37.5mg may be effective for one person another may need 150mg to be effective. Do not just assume because the doctor started you out on one dose that this will work for you. Keep in close contact with your doctor so that adjustments can be made if one dose isn't working for you. I do agree though that family doctors and internists should not be allowed to prescribe psychiatric medications without scheduling psychiatrist followup with their patients first. I know my doctor wrote me the rx when I asked and then just keeps renewing it. Not a good idea. "

464$Condition: Depression$5/12/2010 2:39:40 AM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $1$1$1$I have to say Effexor was THEE WORST drug I've ever taken and i was only taking 75mg! Aside making me feel more depressed, I gained an enormous amount of weight, had blurry vision, felt weak all of the time, restless legs, arms, hands & throat; had less than no sex drive,  and my hair started to fall out (that was the last straw). Getting off of it s u c k s. The side effects were so bad, I was afraid to come off it completely so I cut down to the lowest dose for as long as I could until finally I stopped it altogether...but not before having the worst episode of blind rage I've ever had in my life, followed by anxiety attacks, brain shocks, and dizziness. Took almost two weeks after I stopped the drug completely to not feel any of the things above. Sure, I can be a depressed person (hence, why I take anti-depressants!) but Effexor made me an ultra-depressed crazy person and to be honest, i'm not sure how it has FDA approval. But again..this is just my experience, others have had success.

The worst withdrawl symptom was a nauseous dizzy feeling in my head. I could not move around without feeling as though my brain were somewhat disconnected from my head. It would worsen with each day to the point of nearly vomiting! Let me be very clear here
column2: I could not move my body without feeling like I was going to barf! And I have an iron stomach!

column1: Another serious effect that I have experienced is hand tremors. It has been 12 years since I began taking Effexor XR and 4 years since I stopped and my hands still shake
column2: sometimes so bad that people ask me if I have Parkinson's Disease!! Most of the time people say nothing but look at me like I am a junkie! I have been to the Doc and they ran tests and have no explanation- even though I KNOW that I never had this problem until I went on Effexor XR.

column1: I would recommend this pill because it helped me overcome a severe depression but I caution strongly against it if you have a hard time keeping a pill schedule.
The Doc's didn't want me to go off of the pill. They said depression was ""in my genes"" and I would fight it my whole life. Well
column2: as a biologist
column3: let me tell you that THAT is NOT always the case. I have been anti-depressant free for 4 years and I have never felt more clear
column4: fresh
column5: raw and happy than I do now. Sure there are bummers
column6: sometimes every day. But I just focus on the good parts and count my blessings with my shakey fingers every moment I remember to! "

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$5$"Effexor XR is not effective until you get to the 150mg threshold.  It is FDA approved up to 225mg/day
column3: but many doctors prescribe way higher than this with good results.  I saw one post on here where the person said the drug didn't work and they were at 37.5mg/day.  Yes
column4: the drug will have virtually no effect on you at that low dosage!!

column1: I've been on it a year and I'm at 300mg/day.  It is a wonderful medicine
column2: but I don't like the sweating and the fact that it raises blood pressure.  People
column3: DO NOT trust your primary care or family doctor to know about these psychoactive drugs.  They mean well
column4: but a Psychiatrist is where you need to go for the guys who know everything about psychoactive drugs.  Also
column5: I am not a doctor
column6: nor do I work for a drug company.  I just wanted to throw some facts out there for people to use so that they can be helped.

column1: 676$Condition: Depression$10/3/2009 12:36:34 AM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$3$3$I took Effexor 150 (mg) for three years.  Missed a dose
column2: here and there
column3: and the withdrawal was intense.  The electric shock feeling was terrifying the first time. I complained to my doctor ans was told that the ""shock"" feeling might actually be a plummet in saratonin levels.  So
column4: on my own
column5: I cut back
column6: first to 75mg per day and then half again.  I was able to go dose free for 2-3 days before the ""shock"" would come and I'd take a pill.  I continued just treating the ""shocks"" as they came until I was pill free for days
column7: then weeks at a time.  If you are ready to wean off Effexor
column8: get your doctor to lower and break up your dosage (instead of 2x75mg per day
column9: ask for 4x32.5). This will help you begin slowly skipping one dose and so on.  Effexor is a fantastic medication and it doesn't have to be a nightmare (literally) to come off it.  Pay attention to your ""shocks"" or crashes as you lower your dosage and treat only when you feel them.  It will work.  I was completely off the medication within three months and I had very little hardship. "

column1: 832$Condition: Depression$5/30/2009 3:21:48 PM$Reviewer: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$3$5$"Had anx. most my life.  Then hit with some depression few months ago. Wow

Found out ""it don't work that way"" I guess the depression came on slowly (thou I never realized) and it goes away slowly.  So I seemed to feel best in the evening and worst in the morning. Dr. said that's normal with depression. The other hurdle to get over is I'll be feeling like my old self for a day or two and ""boom"" out of the clear blue it creeps back.  Which at first really scared me and pissed me off.  How dare it
column9: after all that hard work. But
column10: with patience I slowly start feeling better again. Quite a roller coaster ride. To date
column11: I have more better days than bad days. Having to work hard at feeling just ""normal"" does suck.  But life is worth it. With so many horrible things that can happen to us
column12: I try to feel fortunate compared to those who have no real hope.  Regarding people with suicide thoughts
column13: as long as you keep them as thoughts
column14: just don't act on them.  I'm sure every adult has wondered about suicide at some point. Someone once told me that suicide is a ""Final solution to a Temporary problem"". Think about it very true.

column1: Depression/Anx are the most treatable of mental disorders.  So hang in there
column2: take baby steps
column3: and believe in the BIG Guy.  That's all I'm doing. "

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$2$5$Effexor XR worked great for my depression and anxiety but I need to come off it (it's too expensive) and the withdrawal is horrible. I have been off it for a week and I am constantly dizzy (even feel dizzy in my dreams) and often nauseous.  I am also really irritable and am trying to avoid my co-workers so I don't bite anyone's head off for no reason. When I'm not irritable I feel weepy and lately anxious and paranoid.  I have already started taking Wellbutrin and I think it is helping.  It is very frustrating that none of the literature talks about length of withdrawal symptoms.  I know it's different for everyone but surely someone has measured this in a test group and can publish the results from that group.  I haven't even been able to find a comment anywhere from someone saying they managed to get off it and are now finally feeling better.  Very disheartening.  Published tests of new drugs should include discontinuation symptoms and observed length of those symptoms. There is no good reason to exclude that data.

1021$Condition: Depression$1/18/2009 4:44:24 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$5$Miracle drug with nearly immediate results.loved it( but fairly costly), after 1 yr. I felt cured, but had to take it because of tremendous physical withdrawl.standard reduction not tolerable. So I did it my own way, zoloft was cheaper. I continued my Rx of Effexor as ordered & started zoloft at 25mg.(sort of did it like a starter pack). As I increased the Zoloft, I decreased the Effexor. Took me about 2 wks just listening to my body & emotions.Had to go for 150mg of zoloft initially & now have been able to decrease that without the nasty withdrawls. I started Effexor cause I was a mess & the Zoloft just wouldnt cut it at first. I have improved my ways through counseling & feel better, but initially I do believe the Effexor was a much need lifesaver. I have noticed a little less 'drive/motivation' since switching meds but for now I've got a handle on it. I prefer Effexor XR--bless the day it ever goes generic!

1024$Condition: Depression$1/16/2009 8:00:54 PM$Reviewer: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $2$2$5$It is an easy drug to use, just swallow it once a day. I have been on it for 12 years. I've tried to self wean myself off of it but can't.  The original prescribing doctor left the state six months after putting me on it but said it would only take a year for me to stablize emotionally and be taken off of it. Since going on it I have been diagnosed with Disassociative Personality Disorder; I have also become an alcoholic. When I told my doctor how much I drank, he told me I really shouldn't do that any more. I am suicidal but benefit from the personality disorder since part of me remains the caretaker of human beings and animals and birds that I have been for my whole life. My brother shot his rifle at me because I had refused to let him molest me at less than 9 years of age, my father both sexually assualted and abused me at an early age and also told me that I should have been killed as a defective being; my mother told me from an early age that as the second born twin I would have been killed at birth had I been born in Africa. (note: I'm not African). I thought Effexor RX would help me get through a difficult stage as a government whistle blower. Instead I am addicted to it and lorazapan and alcohol. If I didn't have the ability and opportunity to care for beings and creatures less fortunate, I would have left this world.  No, I don't think any medicene that requires taking it for 12 years and with no end in sight is good. Treating a symptom does not treat the person or the cause.  And anyone on these meds should realize that most medical studies only look at the complications of usage for 6 months or less. The analytical side of me tells me that there is something very wrong in an advanced society that perpetuates drug usage rather than helping individuals to overcome emotional trauma.

1035$Condition: Depression$1/9/2009 4:36:27 PM$Reviewer: mpenkava, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$1$4$I am currently taking Effexor XR
column2: and I have been taking it for the past 3-4 years (at least). I became depressed early in High School when I underwent extensive back surgery and my parents got a divorce. These two events happened simultaneously
column3: and my father falsely blamed me for the divorce. This led to my severe depression and self-hatred. I convinced my father to let me talk to my General Practitioner about depression
column4: because he doesn't believe in ""Shrinks."" After trying many other antidepressants (Prozac
column5: Lexapro
column6: Elavil
column7: and others)
column8: my GP decided to start me on Effexor. I was 15 years old at the time. I was not made aware of the drug's short half-life
column9: nor was I told of the extreme dependence I would develop. I have been taking a very high dose (300mg daily) since I began the drug
column10: and I absolutely hate it. As far as my depression symptoms go
column11: this drug has been very effective in controlling them. However
column12: if I miss just one dose
column13: I suffer extreme ""brain shocks
column14: dizziness
column15: chills
column17: and other withdrawal symptoms. I have talked with my GP about stopping this drug
column18: but she will not assist me with it
column19: because she believes I need to take it at least until I graduate from college. I am currently searching for a Psychiatrist who will understand this drug more thoroughly and who will help me break my addiction. I do not want to live my life dependent on a drug
column20: and I wish I had never begun taking Effexor. Please consider VERY carefully the side effects and the dependence-causing qualities of this drug before you agree to take it. Also
column21: be sure your doctor fully understands your condition. If you are suffering from a mental illness
column22: speak to a Psychiatrist or Mental Therapist
column23: not just your Family Doctor or General Practitioner. This medication is highly habit-forming. Please beware."

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $2$1$4$"I've taken several medications for recurrent severe depression over the last 15 years. column3: irritability and even though I do not drink alcohol I felt hung-over every morning. Called the doctor and started cutting back the dosage over a few weeks. Now that I am not taking the drug at all I am miserable. I cannot sleep at night

column1: I wish I had learned more about this drug before I began taking it. Any benefit I had during the first 3 months do not outweigh the side-effects and horrible withdrawal. This is a drug of last resort. Use with caution."

1111$Condition: Depression$11/18/2008 8:56:08 PM$Reviewer: M, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$5$5$I have suffered from Chronic Depression, Panic Disorder, and Social Anxiety for a very long time now and it has only gotten worse over the years. Effexor has worked the best of any drug I have tried in regards to Depression and Panic treatment. I am now up to 225mg per day, and I think I found my correct dosage. It has been months since I have experienced any panic attacks, and severe depression bouts are virtually gone as well. If you have started this medication, be sure to converse with your doctor frequently to find the dose that is best for you. Also, this is an SNRI drug- which means it works for serotonin and norepinephran- but, the benefits of norepinephran cannot be seen at a low dose; if you stop increasing at an early stage, you may as well be taking an ordinary SSRI like Zoloft, etc.

column1: 1159$Condition: Depression$10/20/2008 2:12:58 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$4$5$"To those saying Effexor should be removed from the market
column2: let's be fair - different meds work in different ways for different people. It is your (along with your doctor's) responsibility to research new medications before starting to put them into your body. My doctor warned me about the side effects and let me make the decision to try Effexor to determine if the benefits outweigh the detriments. I have experienced increased sweating (I knew that to be a possible side effect) as well as the withdrawal symptoms many have described (""electrical storm in the head""
column3: dizziness
column4: etc.) but luckily
column5: I knew what to expect and the effects were manageable. It is absolutely IMPERATIVE that you discuss ramping the dosage up/down when you start/stop Effexor XR. If your health care provider does not mention the possible withdrawal symptoms associated with missing a dosage or stopping Effexor ""cold turkey""
column6: they do not know enough about this medication to be prescribing it. If this medication does not work for you (give it 6-10 weeks for full effect)
column7: taper the dosage and get off - try something else. I only remain on Effexor because it works to manage my depression. As common sense would indicate
column8: do not stay on this medication if the benefits do not outweigh the side effects. The withdrawal symptoms will be worse than any of the side effects you experience on Effexor
column9: but they ARE temporary (so far as we know) and will go away after ~ one week. I have been on and off different dosages for years and can tell you that it's not a drug to put in your body unless you are aware of and understand the potential undesired effects."

column1: 1249$Condition: Depression$9/8/2008 5:27:03 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$4$5$"I guess the fact that a drug doesn't work on some individuals doesn't make it a BAD or DANGEROUS drug then
column2: when it DOES help or work on some others. I've read up the reviews on most antidepressants & can see that almost everyone experiences side-effects & withdrawal symptoms - some none
column3: some mild
column4: & others severe. They say ""No pain no gain.""

column2: so it's best if one does some research on their own & not rely fully on their doctor for info.

column1: One has to weigh the pros. & cons. of taking a drug themselves
column2: not getting discouraged by others' unpleasant experiences. For example
column3: before taking Effexor
column4: I was sad 24/7. I would curl up in bed whole day
column5: re-playing hurtful & unpleasant memories from past
column6: & getting so worked up over them (angry/sad) all over again. I kept thinking of all sorts of sad things & just cried & cried. I wanted my husband to stay with me all the time; I was so demanding. I didn't want to go out or do anything. My world was so dark & gloomy. I even got suicidal
column7: thinking of quick & painless ways to die. Everything seemed hopeless
column8: like I was never going to get better
column9: ever. I just wanted to die. Or I believed I was seriously going insane. Now
column10: although Effexor mostly makes me so drowsy & fatigued & causes some other inconveniences
column11: I'd rather suffer from these for a while than go back to the miserable & horrifying state I was in
column12: which was a whole lot more difficult for others to deal with.

column2: if you can afford it
column3: try counseling by a psychologist. It sped up my recovery by miles."

column2: 45-54 on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"I have worked for several years with my doctor and mental health therapist to find ways to minimize the symptoms of chronic depression with exacerbations of seasonal affective disorder.  After much experimentation we hit on the combination of taking Wellbutrin year-round for the chronic depression and adding Effexor XR in varying doses throughout 9 months of the year to treat the seasonl affective disorder.

column1: I start taking 37.5 mg of Effexor in the middle of August
column2: increasing to 75 mg at the middle of October and to 112.5 mg at the end of November.  I maintain that dose all winter
column3: until the beginning of April when I begin decreasing the dose at about 3-week intervals so that I'm off the Effexor by the middle of May.

column1: I have tried decreasing the dose more quickly than that
column2: but like many others have reported
column3: the side effects made me very uncomfortable.  (I have learned
column4: when weaning off
column5: to carry one 37.5 mg capsule with me to take if I'm feeling especially uncomfortable
column6: but find I have rarely needed to take it.)

column1: While the medicine has been indispensable in relieving my suffering
column2: I also must report the importance of behavioral interventions – showering and getting dressed every day
column3: getting outside daily (even if it’s just to sit on the porch)
column4: calling or visiting friends when I’m feeling down
column5: and seeing my mental health therapist and/or doctor when I’m feeling overwhelmed.  They help me to see how my thoughts may be contributing to the depression and how I can get back on track.

column2: don’t give up.  Try the interventions your doctor suggests
column3: and let him or her know what works and what doesn’t so that your treatment can be tailored to you.

1324$Condition: Depression$6/23/2008 9:40:21 PM$Reviewer: Vase, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $4$3$4$I have been taking effexor for about 15 years, along with other antidepressants. (I've been on antidepressants since 1975.) I take 300mg in the morning and 75mg at night, along with Wellbutrin. . Effexor has worked very well most of the time. I still have the chronic crashes occasionally that can last for months, but that is the nature of the disease. I have none of the nausea, dizzy, or aggressive etc symptoms I read about here. The addictiveness is the only negative. I have gone into severe and dibilitating withdrawal when trying to trim down the dosage.  If I miss a dose I start wringing my hands, and become jumpy and fearful - even irrational. That makes me paranoid about running out, not being able to afford it, etc. even to the point of panic attacks. Antidepressants are also sneaky because you can think you are well and don't need it, when actually it is the pills themselves that make you better. If given a choice, I would still take the medication. It keeps me mostly non-suicidal (very rare - usually if pill supply is threatened) and as stable as one can expect. Yes I get angry about addictiveness, but I really appreciate not being so severely depressed, and being able to be functional, and at times even happy. I know too well the opposite.

I would NEVER recommend taking this regardless of how bad you think your depression is. column1: 1381$Condition: Depression$5/10/2008 1:28:04 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$4$5$"I have been taking Effexor XR 75mg for 4.5 years now.  It has given me my life back.
It took me a long time to admit that I might be depressed
column2: as I didn't want to face what I perceived as a stigma against depressed folks as deficient in character
column3: lacking in faith
column4: or ""crazy.""  Finally things got so bad (not getting out of bed on the weekends
column5: suicidal thoughts)
column6: that I

column1: gave up"" and went to see a counselor.  That was the best decision of my life (other than marrying my wife.. although I guess you could say that THAT wouldn't have happened had I not sought help!).
So after seeking help seven years ago I was diagnosed with double depression and started off with Prozac.  That didn't work
column2: so switched to Zoloft.  Zoloft worked on my depression and I can vividly remember the joy of seeing leaves rustle in sunlight about 5 weeks after starting Zoloft and feeling happy for the first time years.  I gained 20 pounds of fat and lost my sex drive almost completely
column3: but I was so happy to be ""alive"" again that I lived with those side effects for a couple of years.  Eventually I wanted more
column4: so I dropped Zoloft cold turkey
column5: lost weight
column6: sex drive came back
column7: but so did depression.  Finally got on Effexor XR and it has been a miracle.  A little sex drive lessening but not a lot
column8: and no sexual function problems at all.  My depression has stayed away for the 4 years I've been on this drug.

column1: This drug has worked wonders for me
column2: and I hope that it will for you.  Realize that no one drug works for everyone
column3: and that you do have to try out different medications to find the one for you.

column1: One thing -- if I skip a dose I can immediately tell
column2: because I get a little dizzy
column3: a little headache
column4: etc.  I've heard that trying to go off Effexor can be very tricky.  Apparently if you want to go off you need to gradually lower the dose or switch to another med that can help while you're coming off of Effexor and then ""wean"" off of that.

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $3$2$3$Treatment wasn't bad...until I decided to go off of it. I was given a heavy dose 300 mg/day. On it for ~18 months. Started to reduce the dosage and what I call 'neurochemelectrical discharges' started zapping my brain. It was tolerable and expected. Kept reducing the dosage slowly as directed. Finally made it down to 37.5mg/1x day and the 'neurochemeletrical' circus was raging...but slightly tolerable. Went totally off and felt like I was back in college having the worst psychadelic experience of my life. Called the Dr. and picked up two more titration packets with the 37.5s and eased them back in and then started staggering them every other day and longer. My brain finally settled down a little. I was ready to stop again
column3: and did so. I was still seeing (and mostly feeling...tracers) but they were tolerable. I was off for 8 days...yes 8 (eight
column5: etc.) so it was out of my system but the psychadelic party was still going. I broke down and took a 75mg capsule I had...just in case... Bottom line. THIS STUFF IS REALLY
column6: REALLY DIFFICULT TO GET OFF OF! Please consider this if your Dr. suggests it. Believe me
column7: I know how bad things may seem
column8: but please consider all options. I now have to start the original (or generic) Effexor at 25 mg for 7 days and then split them to 12.5 mg for 7 days. I am pretty tough (now anyway...) by most standards but this (withdrawl) is
column9: in my opinion
column10: worse than depression. I know how to take care of that now without meds. Just please look into it before getting on it.

35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$4$3$"I have been on Effexor for approximately 4 years now.

column1: Overall I really have really liked this medication. It has had an impact on my life. I had social anxiety disorder as well as depression. Both of them were cleared up for a long time.

column2: I burned out at my job last year and have ended up in the hospital for depression. I don't really want to say that my medication didn't work because I think I really caused my burnout (working 80+ hours/week
column3: volunteering
column4: etc.) My doctor bumped up my dosage from 150 to 225 and that seems to have helped me (along with a lot of therapy). Sometimes I am concerned though that maybe it is losing its effect on me. I hope not... I am not sure what I would change to.

column1: It was sort of rough in the beginning of taking this medication - I was hyper and it was harder to sleep. Those effects wore off after a couple of months.
Now my side effects seem to include night sweats (sometimes the sheets are wet)
column2: weight gain (some
column3: but it could just be that I am getting older)
column4: and my orgasms are different (its like I feel them through a filter). If I miss taking it for a few hours I feel vertigo and sort of out of body. Miss two days and I just quit moving. It sucks. I try to avoid that at all costs now :)

column1: Overall I am pleased with this medication. I was on Paxil before and all I felt like doing was stare at the wall.

column3: I know.  It took quite a while to understand how it effected my body
column4: and the proper times to take it
column5: so that its side effects fit my schedule.  To avoid being tired
column6: I started taking the medication at 5:00 AM (150mg) so that I could sleep for an hour after taking it
column7: thereby avoiding the exhausted feeling mid-morning.  I take my other dose (150mg) at 10:00 PM
column8: or right before bed.  IMPORTANT - Do not stop taking this medicine ""cold turkey"" and definitely talk to your doctor before you change the dosage.  Contrary to early studies
column9: this drug has addictive properties that manifest themselves in the form of EXTREME vertigo.  I ran out of medicine for two days
column10: by the morning of the third day
column11: I could barely walk without weaving and bumping into things.  The emergency room doctor told me this was due to my abrupt change in dosage
column12: and after a day of taking my medicine
column13: I was fine."

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $1$1$5$I was prescribed Effexor XR (150mg) which I took in conjunction with Zoloft (200mg) and valium (5mg x 3) to treat my depression and anxiety.  Initially I experienced benefits from the medication
column3: but eventually these benefits were replaced by negative side-effecs which crippled me.  I gradually discontinued the Zoloft (against medical advice) and my health improved dramatically!  I continued to take the Effexor
column4: although the therapeutic benefits diminished and I was plagued with dark
column5: destructive and suicidal thoughts.  I decided to wean myself off of the Effexor (against doctor's advice again).  It took me about 2 months gradually reducing the dosage (sometimes increasing it again when withdrawal symptoms occurred).  Today I use only diazepam (5mg x 3) to control anxiety and panic.  My experience with prescription antidepressants is that the initial benefits diminish over time to be replaced by negative side-effects.  Effexor may be a good short-term therapy
column6: but over time the side-effects increased and the benefits disappeared.  Diazepam in the only prescription that has provided consistent
column7: continuous and effective treatment.
